During hydrogen production by hydrolysis of ammonia borane (AB), transition metal oxides act as active sites in the catalyst and can help to achieve rapid and large-scale release of hydrogen, but its catalytic mechanism is still under discussion. We developed a Cu2O/CuO catalyst with precisely controlled valence states and identified the fundamental source of the catalytic activity of oxides. The successive changes in the Cu valence state content of Cu2O/CuO resulted in a volcano-like trend of the catalyst activity, with the optimal hydrogen production rate from hydrolysis reaching 378.01 mL·g−1·min−1. The characterization of the catalysts after combined use revealed that AB prompted the catalyst surface to reconstruct during the catalytic process, forming a Cu/Cu2O heterostructure. This study established, for the first time, the structure-activity relationship between the valence state of copper and its catalytic activity, providing a theoretical basis for the construction of copper-based catalysts for AB hydrolysis. Graphical Abstract Keywords Dehydrogenation Ammonia borane Copper oxide Catalysts Valence regulation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen storage materials are an effective way to store and transport hydrogen as an energy carrier, and the possibility of preparing hydrogen on-site for utilization can be realized by hydrolyzing stable boron derivative hydrogen storage materials [1–4]. Ammonia borane (NH3BH3, AB) has been the subject of research interest due to its high hydrogen storage content (19.6 wt%), non-toxicity, low molecular weight, and stability [5]. AB is capable of releasing hydrogen in several ways [6,7], including a mild hydrolysis reaction that produces 3 equivalents of hydrogen from the 1 mol AB, but the reaction requires the participation of a catalyst [8–10]. Metal-based catalysts are typically observed to exhibit excellent catalytic activity, whereas non-noble metal catalysts display comparatively poorer catalytic activity and stability relative to those based on noble metals [11–13]. Transition metal compounds (borides, phosphides, oxides, etc.) have been increasingly studied to enhance the stability of small-sized non-noble metal catalysts that are highly susceptible to oxidation. Among these, transition metal oxides (TMOs) exert a beneficial effect on the effective activation and dissociation of H2O molecules in the AB hydrolysis reaction, which can effectively increase the hydrogen production rate [14,15]. Copper-, cobalt-, and nickel-based oxides have been demonstrated to exhibit catalytic activity[16,17]. Such catalysts are typically combined with metals, in which the oxides act as supports or electron donors, facilitating the dispersion of the metals and increasing the electron density on the metal to assist the metal active sites in catalysis [18,19]. Due to the lack of research on pure oxide catalysts, the fundamental source of their catalytic activity is not fully explored, and its catalytic mechanism remains to be discussed. Most pure oxides related to Co and Ni have no direct catalytic activity for AB. When designing pure oxide catalysts for AB hydrolysis, it is an effective strategy to use copper oxide or metal doping as activation sites to activate the catalyst for catalysis [20–23]. For example, Li et al. demonstrated that the CuO/Co3O4@C catalytic system can markedly enhance the catalytic activity, which was due to the good synergistic effect between the oxides [24]. Butenko et al. also used a small amount of CuO to activate Co3O4 to catalyze, since the reduction of CuO can produce transient Cu−H to excite the reduced state of Co-B for catalytic reaction [25]. It can be seen that copper oxide occupies an important position in AB catalysis-related research. Copper oxides are relatively low in cost, abundant in reserves, simple and versatile in preparation, and copper-based catalysts can be used in a variety of reduction catalytic reactions after catalyzing AB to release hydrogen, which can be used in multiple channels [26–28]. However, it is worth noting that since copper oxide has multiple oxidation states and exhibits different catalytic activities in catalyzing AB reactions, there is currently no systematic study on its influence on catalytic activity [29,30]. Therefore, it is necessary to construct pure copper oxide catalysts to explore the structure-activity relationship and analyze the hydrolysis mechanism, with a view to developing oxide catalysts. A series of Cu2O/CuO nanocubes with tunable Cu valence states were constructed to accurately determine the content of elements in each valence state in the catalyst and investigate its relationship with the catalytic activity. In addition, through a detailed study of the structure and surface characteristics attributes following the catalytic process, it was clarified that the catalytic activity of the oxide comes from surface reconstruction. This comparative study aims to clarify the regularity of hydrogen release from AB hydrolysis catalyzed by pure TMOs and seeks to provide a basis for the construction of TMOs catalysts for hydrogen storage materials hydrolysis. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of Cu2O The small-sized Cu2O nanocubes were synthesized by improving the previously reported method[31]. A solution of 2.88 g sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) in 443 mL deionized water was prepared by continuous stirring for 5 min to ensure complete dissolution. 10 mL of 0.1 M CuSO4 was added to it to form a light blue solution, and 2 mL of 1.0 M NaOH solution was added to the system until the solution turned into a dark blue suspension. Afterward, 45 mL of 0.2 M sodium ascorbate (SA) was added to the above solution, stirred at a constant speed for 5 min, and aged for 55 min to allow crystals to grow. Centrifugation was then employed to obtain the precipitate, which was washed 3 times and subsequently dried oven to produce the Cu2O sample. 2.2 Synthesis of Cu2O/CuO The synthesis method of Cu2O/CuO is to calcine the prepared Cu2O nanocubes in air. To obtain the most optimized composite material, the calcination temperature (100 ∼ 260℃, 4 h) and times (180℃, 2–8 h) were controlled to prepare the composites, and the heating rate was 5℃/min. The corresponding samples are marked as CC n-m h (n = 100℃, 140℃, 180℃, 220℃, 260℃; m=2, 4, 6, 8). 2.3 AB hydrolysis experiments The prepared catalysts were subjected to catalytic AB hydrolysis for hydrogen production at room temperature (25℃), and the volume of hydrogen generated was recorded in real-time using a micro-gas flowmeter (RTK-SGMC). Typically, 20 mg of prepared catalyst was weighed and dispersed in 10 mL of H2O by ultrasonic treatment for 5 min, thereby obtaining a solution with a uniform distribution of catalyst. Afterward, 17.5 mg AB (0.57 mmol) was added to the solution, thereby initiating the reaction. The process of hydrogen production by hydrolysis of AB was described as follows: (1) NH3BH3 + 2H2O → NH4BO2 + 3H2 The specific rates of hydrogen generation (HGR, mL·g−1·min−1) were calculated as: (2) HER = V H2⁄(m cat × t) where V H2 represents the volume (mL) of hydrogen generated under standard atmospheric pressure; mcat is the mass (g) of the prepared catalyst; t is the time required for the hydrolysis reaction (min). The value of turnover frequency (TOF, min−1), which is used to assess the catalytic activity of the catalyst. The calculation was performed as follows: (3) TOF = n H2⁄(n Cu × t) where n H2 represents the moles of hydrogen generated and n Cu represents the moles of Cu elements in the catalyst. To explore the kinetic parameters of the catalytic reaction, AB concentration, catalyst dosage, and reaction temperature of the catalytic reaction were changed for testing. To assess the durability of the Cu2O/CuO catalyst, the hydrogen volume was monitored until each reaction no longer changed, and then the catalyst was separated from the reaction solution by centrifugation and redispersed in new AB solution for the next catalytic use, for a total of five cycles. 3 Results and discussion The specific synthesis route of small-sized Cu2O/CuO is shown in Scheme 1. Firstly, copper hydroxide is formed by copper salt solution and sodium hydroxide under the action of surfactant SDS, and then Cu2O nanocubes are obtained after SA reduction and aging for a while. The final stage comprised the controlled calcination of Cu2O under air conditions, causing it to oxidize gradually from the outside to the inside, thus producing a series of Cu2O/CuO catalysts[32]. To explore the phase changes and crystal structure of the Cu2O/CuO as the calcination temperature and time change. The diffraction peak of the prepared Cu2O in the XRD patterns in Fig. 1a corresponds to cubic phase Cu2O (JCPDS no. 05–0667). As the calcination temperature changes, the emergence of new diffraction peaks at 35.5°, 38.7°, 49.1°, which can be attributed to (022), (111), and (−202) crystal planes of monoclinic CuO (JCPDS no. 45–0937), respectively. This result shows that the increase in calcination temperature causes Cu2O to gradually transform into CuO, and the catalyst forms mixed-valence copper oxide. When the calcination temperature is controlled at 180°C, as the calcination time increases (Fig. 1b), the intensity of the CuO diffraction peak increases slightly from the original basis, indicating that the Cu2O/CuO phase structure of copper oxide is more accurately controlled. The phase change was further determined by FTIR (Fig. 1c), of which the absorption bands at 3456 and 1629 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching and bending vibrations of the O−H bond and hydroxyl groups of surface-adsorbed water, respectively. The absorption band at 628 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of Cu(I)−O in the Cu2O phase, while the absorption band at 497 cm−1 corresponds to the vibration of the Cu(II)−O in the CuO phase [33,34]. With the calcination temperature and time increased, the absorption band corresponding to Cu(II)−O at 497 cm−1 increases significantly, which proves that Cu2O is converted into CuO during the calcination process to form a heterogeneous structure of Cu2O/CuO. The Rietveld method was used to refine the phase structure of the catalyst under different calcination conditions using the Rietan-2000 program. The calculated fits demonstrate a high degree of correlation with the XRD data obtained from the original tests, exhibiting only minor fluctuations in the error curves (Fig. 1d and e). The same is true for the other sample data results shown in Fig. S1. The refined crystal structure parameters are listed in Table 1, and the R-weighted pattern (Rwp) shows the reliability of the results. As the calcination temperature and time of synthetic Cu2O/CuO increase, the Cu2O content decreases while the CuO content increases, indicating that Cu2O is gradually oxidized to CuO. Moreover, the cubic phase Cu2O unit cell parameter gradually decreases, indicating that the crystal lattice shrinks significantly as the CuO content increases, while the monoclinic phase CuO lattice has enlargement and distortion. The change of phase content in the catalyst causes the lattice structure to be distorted. The above demonstrates that the close contact between Cu2O and CuO results in a change of each lattice constant in response to alterations in the oxidation degree. The micromorphology of the synthesized copper oxides was observed by SEM, and all showed uniform nanoparticles (Fig. S2). The average particle size (diagonal) of CC180–6h is about 70.6 nm, slightly smaller than Cu2O, and the surface roughness is slightly increased. The TEM and HRTEM images in Fig. 2 reveal the microscopic morphology and structural changes of the prepared Cu2O and Cu2O/CuO. Initially, Cu2O is approximately a nanocubic structure, and the lattice spacing of 0.22 nm conforms to the (200) plane of Cu2O, which displays a single-crystal structure as evidenced by its selected area electron diffraction (SAED) image (Fig. 2d). After calcination, CC180–6h still maintains a cubic shape, but the pore structure within it exhibited a notable increase, akin to dice shape. These pores served to facilitate the catalytic mass transfer process, thereby enhancing the overall catalytic efficiency. Fig. 2g shows that the lattice spacing of 0.22 and 0.31 nm are indicative of the (200) and (110) planes of Cu2O, in addition, 0.23 and 0.25 nm, corresponding to the (111) and (002) planes of CuO, respectively. It is also obvious that the CuO phase lattice is wrapped around Cu2O phase, mainly located on the outside, and two copper oxides are in good contact, similar to the formation of a core-shell structure of Cu2O@CuO. The SAED image of CC180–6h (Fig. 2h) also confirmed the polycrystalline mixed phase structure. The elemental mapping image (Fig. 2i) further confirmed that there is no element aggregation in Cu2O/CuO and the Cu and O elements are evenly distributed. The pore structure of the catalyst before and after calcination was further explored and confirmed by the N2 adsorption-desorption test. The measured isotherms are shown in Fig. S3 and can be characterized as type IV isotherms, which provides evidence for the existence of a mesoporous structure. The specific surface area of CC180–6h is 18.60 m2/g, which is slightly higher than that of Cu2O before calcination (16.06 m2/g), and its pore volume also increases slightly. This result indicates that calcination does not cause substantial alterations to the pore structure of the catalyst, thus the impact of pore structure modifications on catalytic performance is negated, facilitating the control of the Cu chemical state as the main influencing factor. XPS was used to characterize and analyze the element state of the sample. Fig. S4 shows the survey of the characterization of copper oxides obtained under different preparation conditions, in which only Cu, O, and C elements exist, indicating the purity of the structure. The fitting curves of the Cu element are shown in the high-resolution XPS spectra ( Fig. 3a and S5). For the pristine Cu2O, the peaks at 932.8 and 952.8 eV correspond to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Cu+, 934.5 and 954.5 eV corresponded to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Cu2+, respectively[35,36]. Concurrently, the fitting curve contains satellite peaks of extremely low intensity, which indicates that there is a trace amount of Cu2+. Since the Cu2O sample was slightly oxidized during the characterization test process, some Cu2+ existed, and its content only accounted for 21.3 % of the Cu element. As the calcination temperature and duration of the series of samples increased, the Cu2+ content gradually increased up to 80.1 %, and the trend is shown in the curve of Fig. 3c. The high-resolution spectra of O 1s are also shown in Fig. 3b, which were fitted to the lattice oxygen (Olatt) at 529.7 eV and 530.4 eV corresponding to Cu2+ and Cu+ in CuO and Cu2O, respectively, and 531.5 eV is the surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads) [32]. The Olatt(Cu2+) content gradually increases, while the Olatt(Cu+) and Oads content gradually decreases, which also indicates the increase of CuO content in the samples. Calculating the average valence state of the Cu element in the copper oxide samples, also shows a gradually increasing trend (Fig. 3c). However, the CuO content calculated by XPS analysis is significantly higher than that obtained by XRD refinement. Due to the fact the scanning depth of XRD technology is deeper than XPS which mainly obtains surface information, indicating that the oxidation process proceeds from the outside to the inside, and also proves that the mixed-phase Cu2O/CuO is a core-shell structure[37]. The catalytic hydrolysis performance of Cu2O/CuO catalysts was investigated. Fig. 4a and b show the curves of the volume of hydrogen produced by hydrolysis over time. The catalyst calcined at 180°C released all hydrogen in the shortest time, and the HGR could reach 99.21 mL·g−1·min−1. By controlling the calcination time at 180°C, it was found that the HGR of CC180–6h could reach 135.53 mL·g−1·min−1, which is 3.01 times that of the prepared Cu2O, and the corresponding TOF value is 1.30 min−1. The enhancement comes from the formation of a mixed-phase structure of Cu2O and CuO compared to single-phase, and the interface formed by the appropriate phase content promotes the catalyst activity. Based on the changes in CuO content in Cu2O/CuO determined by the refined XRD, revealed a first increasing and then decreasing trend in the HGR with increasing CuO content, similar to the volcanic type (Fig. 4c), and the activity is optimal only when the CuO content is about 40 %. The time plots of hydrogen evolution versus various concentrations of AB are shown in Fig. 4d. At 298 K, although the total amount of hydrogen produced by CC180–6h at each AB concentration is different, the hydrogen release curves overlapped in the initial stage, and the HGR is almost the same. The slope between the logarithmic of hydrogen generation and AB concentration is 0.01, indicating that the catalytic rate of CC180–6h is linearly independent of AB concentration, which excludes the possibility that AB activation alone is a rate-determining step[24,38]. Different amounts of CC180–6h catalyst were used to carry out AB hydrolysis at room temperature to study the effect of catalyst amount on catalytic activity. The rate of the catalytic reaction exhibited a gradual increase with the dosage of the catalyst, reaching an HGR of 294.68 mL·g−1·min−1 at a dosage of 40 mg. The amount of catalyst is linearly correlated with HGR. The aforementioned results indicate that the hydrolysis process of AB is not constrained by the diffusion of reactants, and that the reaction rate is contingent upon the specific structure of the catalyst employed. Kinetic experiments were carried out at temperatures between 298 and 318 K, and the hydrogen generation curves demonstrated a linear correlation (Fig. 4f). According to the Arrhenius plot, the activation energy (E a) of the AB hydrolysis reaction catalyzed by CC180–6h was determined to be 36.3 kJ·mol−1 (Fig. 4i). CC180–6h catalyzes the hydrolysis of HGR to 378.01 mL·g−1·min−1 at 318 K, with a TOF value of 3.62 min−1. Besides, the catalytic activity of copper-containing non-noble metal catalysts and the E a required for the reaction were compared (Table S1). The catalytic activity of CC180–6h prepared in this study is better than that of some catalysts reported in the literature, and even better than that of noble metal catalyst Au@Cu2O (1.41 min−1)[11], while the E a is also lower than some of the reported values[39,40]. This lower E a value provides further evidence that the heterogeneous structures effectively reduce the energy barrier of the catalytic reaction and improve the catalytic activity. To gain insight into the fundamental mechanisms underlying catalyst activity and the associated changes, the used catalysts were subjected to detailed characterization analysis. The XRD patterns of the catalyst after use are shown in Fig. 5a. Compared with the Cu2O/CuO mixed-phase structure, the emergence of new diffraction peaks in the patterns of a series of used samples at 43.3 and 50.4° is indicative of the (111) and (200) crystal planes of metallic Cu (JCPDS no. 4–836), respectively. Conversely, the diffraction peaks of CuO are no longer present, thereby confirming the formation of the Cu/Cu2O structure exclusively. This is due to the reductive properties of AB, which enables the reduction of the oxidized metal during the catalytic process while maintaining the original microstructure[41,42]. For the series of Cu2O/CuO catalysts, as the CuO content in the catalyst increases, the corresponding Cu0 content in the Cu/Cu2O catalyst after use also shows an increasing trend. The structure contents and cell parameters of the catalyst after use were accurately determined by refined XRD (Fig. S6), and the relevant data results are shown in Table 2. The Cu content in the used catalyst is close to the CuO content in the Cu2O/CuO original catalyst, which indicates that the CuO content affects the Cu content in the used catalyst. The electronic state of the catalyst surface after use was analyzed using XPS, and the Cu 2p spectra of the catalyst after use are shown in Fig. 5b. The peaks at 932.4 and 952.3 eV can correspond to Cu0 and Cu+, and there are also peaks indicating less Cu2+. The specific contents are listed in Table S2. O 1 s spectrum analysis also shows similar content results (Fig. S7). Combined with the XRD results, the presence of Cu2+ in the sample is due to partial oxidation of the surface during the XPS sample preparation process. Since the binding energy values of Cu+ and Cu0 in XPS Cu 2p spectra are close, Cu LMM Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) spectra were used to distinguish them (Fig. 5c). The characteristic peaks of Cu+ (916.7 eV) and Cu0 (918.7 eV) proved the co-existence of Cu2O and metal Cu [36,43]. As shown in Fig. 5h, the calculated relative contents show that the Cu0 in used catalysts (without considering the CuO content) increases with the CuO content in the original Cu2O/CuO, which were close to the results obtained by refined XRD. That is because compared with Cu2O, CuO is easier to be reduced to a Cu structure, and is more conducive to surface reconstruction by AB reduction during the catalytic process to form a Cu/Cu2O structure [44]. The CuO content in the original Cu2O/CuO catalyst and the corresponding Cu0 content in the catalyst after use presents a relatively proportional relationship, which in turn affects the catalytic activity, causing the catalytic activity to show a volcano-like change with the increase of CuO content. At the same time, the microscopic morphology of the catalyst after use showed no significant changes compared to before use, which is still in the shape of nanocubes, with an average particle size consistent with CC180–6h (Fig. 5d and e). As shown in Fig. 5f, a detailed observation of the crystal plane shows that the lattice spacing of 0.22 nm corresponds to the (200) plane of Cu2O, and 0.21 nm corresponds to the (111) plane of Cu, showing good contact between the two phases. The SAED image of CC180–6h-A also confirmed the mixed phase structure (Fig. 5g). The above shows that the catalyst still maintains its original microscopic morphology after use, and only undergoes phase changes to form a Cu/Cu2O heterogeneous structure. Meanwhile, the recyclability of the catalyst was tested. After complete hydrolysis of AB, the reaction solution was removed to continue the catalytic reaction by dispersing the catalyst in a new AB solution. Fig. 5i and j show the hydrogen generation and the percentage of catalyst activity retained during the subsequent AB hydrolysis process. As the time required to release all the hydrogen in each cycle increased, the turn-off frequency used gradually decreased. The hydrogen yield of AB approximately reached 100 % following each of the five uses, and it still maintained 98.1 % of the original activity after three catalytic uses, but its activity decreased significantly after subsequent uses. The catalysts were characterized after the third and fifth uses, respectively. It was found that the Cu/Cu2O phase content of the CC180–6h after the third use was close to that after the first use, but the Cu content increased significantly in the fifth use (Fig. S8). The surface element valence analysis also showed that the catalyst after the fifth use still has a Cu/Cu2O structure, except for a small amount of Cu2+ formed by oxidation during the XPS test process, but the Cu0 content was significantly increased to about 60.5 % (Fig. S9). Moreover, the surface roughness of the catalyst increased after the third use, and some adhesion occurred between the particles, but the original cubic shape turned into an irregular morphology after the fifth use but none of them was covered by byproducts (Fig. S10). This is due to the reduction effect of AB, which increased the metal state in the catalyst after multiple uses, causing the catalyst to break and resulting in a decrease in catalytic activity [45]. In addition, as shown in Fig. S11, no obvious B and N elements were observed on the catalyst surface after the third use, but the surface N element increased significantly after the fifth use, indicating that the by-products produced after multiple AB hydrolysis gradually covered the catalyst surface [46]. The above shows that the catalyst after the third use can still maintain the same structure and morphology as after the first use, so the catalytic activity is basically maintained. However, the Cu content of the catalyst after the fifth use is significantly increased and the microstructure is destroyed, the adsorption of N-containing by-products on the surface covered the active sites, which resulted in a significant decrease in the catalyst activity. Besides, the catalyst in the solution after catalytic use was separated to obtain the filtrate, which was measured by UV-Vis spectrophotometer. As shown in Fig. S12, the results show that no obvious absorption peaks appeared in the filtrate after the first and fifth uses of the catalyst, which indicates that no obvious Cu leaching occurred during the use of the catalyst. However, if the catalyst is placed in the reaction solution for a long time, a broad absorption peak will appear in the filtrate at about 620 nm, which corresponds to the absorption of Cu2+ [45]. Since the Cu in the catalyst is leached due to oxidation etching, the catalyst should not be immersed in the reaction solution for a long time after use to prevent catalyst loss. Strategies for oxide catalyst stability remain a target for future research. The catalyst can be optimized by loading and doping, which can stabilize the catalyst morphology while inhibiting the further transformation of the Cu valence state to improve its stability [20,47]. The above analysis indicates that the real active sites of Cu2O/CuO in catalyzing AB hydrolysis reactions are the reduced Cu0 and Cu2O generated by surface reconstruction. To understand the catalytic mechanism of Cu/Cu2O for AB hydrolysis, density functional theory calculations were performed to preliminarily study the adsorption and subsequent dissociation of H2O and AB molecules on the Cu/Cu2O model. As shown in Fig. 6a, the adsorption energy (E ads) of H2O on the Cu surface is −0.44 eV, which is higher than the E ads on the Cu2O surface (−0.76 eV); while the E ads of AB on the Cu surface (−1.81 eV) is lower than that on the Cu2O surface (−1.61 eV). From a thermodynamic point of view, the H2O molecule preferentially interacts with Cu2O sites, while AB molecules tend to adsorb on Cu sites. Fig. 6b and c show the relative free energies of the adsorbed and final states of H2O and AB. The final states of O−H and B−H bond dissociation catalyzed by Cu and Cu2O sites in Cu/Cu2O are both located below the reactants. In comparison, the final free energy of O−H bond dissociation by Cu2O is lower than that of Cu, while the B−H bond dissociation by Cu is lower than that of Cu2O. The above shows that in the heterostructure Cu/Cu2O model, Cu is more conducive to the adsorption and dissociation of AB molecules, while Cu2O tends to dissociate H2O molecules. Combining experimental results with theoretical calculations, a reasonable mechanism explanation for the hydrogen generation process is proposed (Fig. 6d) [24,38,48,49]: (i) The reaction initiates with the adsorption of the reactants, AB and H2O, on the surface of the core-shell structure Cu2O/CuO, causing it to be reduced to form Cu/Cu2O; (ii) Cu and Cu2O act as active sites to activate the B−H bond in AB and the O−H bond in H2O, respectively; (iii) On the surface of Cu2O, the O−H bond in H2O is broken to produce H* and *OH; (iv) The resulting *OH intermediate attacks the B atom in the AB molecule on the Cu surface, causing the B−H bond to break, generating NH3BH2−*OH and H*. Therefore, the two generated H* combine to form H2 molecules, which escape from the catalyst surface; (v) The catalytic process is then repeated until 3 equivalents of H2 are released. Cu/Cu2O serves as dual-active catalytic sites generated in situ, Cu2O which can also act as a substrate helps to anchor the in situ formed metal Cu sites to avoid particle aggregation and the interfacial interactions in the heterostructure may promote the formation of active intermediates, thereby accelerating the catalytic rate. 4 Conclusions Cu2O/CuO heterostructures with controllable valence state content were successfully synthesized, and the catalytic performance was systematically investigated. The Cu2+ content in the Cu2O/CuO increases with the calcination temperature and time, and the catalytic activity shows a volcano-like trend change. The highest catalytic activity was observed when the CuO content reached approximately 41 %, with an HGR of 378.01 mL·g−1·min−1, and the E a required for the reaction is only 36.3 kJ·mol−1. Through detailed investigation and comparison of the catalysts after use, the surface of the Cu2O/CuO catalytic process was reconstructed to form Cu/Cu2O active sites, which activated AB and H2O molecules respectively, and carried out catalytic reactions. This study systematically investigated the structure-activity relationship between the valence state changes and catalytic activity of copper oxide catalysts, which is conducive to the design and exploration of various copper-based oxide catalysts for hydrogen production by hydrolysis of AB. coredata.dc:description: During hydrogen production by hydrolysis of ammonia borane (AB), transition metal oxides act as active sites in the catalyst and can help to achieve rapid and large-scale release of hydrogen, but its catalytic mechanism is still under discussion. We developed a Cu2O/CuO catalyst with precisely controlled valence states and identified the fundamental source of the catalytic activity of oxides. The successive changes in the Cu valence state content of Cu2O/CuO resulted in a volcano-like trend of the catalyst activity, with the optimal hydrogen production rate from hydrolysis reaching 378.01 mL·g−1·min−1. The characterization of the catalysts after combined use revealed that AB prompted the catalyst surface to reconstruct during the catalytic process, forming a Cu/Cu2O heterostructure. This study established, for the first time, the structure-activity relationship between the valence state of copper and its catalytic activity, providing a theoretical basis for the construction of copper-based catalysts for AB hydrolysis.

coredata.dc:title: Ammonia borane-promoted surface reconstruction of copper oxide catalysts for efficient catalytic hydrogen production from hydrolysis
